Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Creating Confined-but-Coupled Nanostructures to Balance Quantum Confinement and Quantum Coupling
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) and the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program (SSMC), both in the Division of Materials Research.
Technical: The research component of this CAREER award is to study semiconductor nanostructures with controlled connections in multiple dimensions that balance quantum confinement and quantum coupling. The conceptual framework underlying the research project is based on analogies between atomic crystals and nanocrystal assemblies as artificial solids. The research builds on recent advances in independent controls of the energy level of the artificial atom (nanocrystal), the quantum coupling across the artificial bond (molecular linker), and the symmetry of the artificial crystal (superlattice). The project aims to significantly advance knowledge and understanding of tunable extended electronic states in coupled nanocrystal assemblies. It studies pressure tuning of inter-nanocrystal separation, formation of permanent artificial bonds between nanostructures, and processing-structure-property relationships of semiconductor nanostructures. The overall objectives of the research are to: (1) map the electronic phase diagram of confined-but-connected semiconductor nanostructures with precise experimental control over the disorder and coupling of the system; (2) apply the understanding of correlated properties in the creation of artificial solids with electronic and optical properties by design, and (3) transform the fundamental understanding into a technological reality by developing and testing prototype photovoltaic test structures.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with high technological relevance. The nanostructured semiconductor materials studied in this project have potential applications in next-generation energy technologies. The educational activities of this CAREER project are designed to: (1) integrate results from the research frontier and education of students ranging from high school, to undergraduate courses and projects, and to graduate school, and (2) capture the enthusiasm and engagement of students in impending energy issues, encouraging their future contributions as the next generation of scientist and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The prospect of designing novel materials with electrical, optical and magnetic properties by design has intrigued scientists and engineers for years.  Building blocks for such ‘designer solids’ have emerged from recent advances in nanomaterial synthesis, characterization, and emerging understanding of their size-dependent properties.  Colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals (or quantum dots) stand out as an intellectually intriguing and experimentally advantageous system for the fundamental study of artificial solids and their technological development.

Progress towards bringing the much-anticipated properties of these designer solids to technological fruition in electronic devices has been limited by the seemingly contradictory requirements of coupling nanostructures while preserving the effects of size-tunable quantum confined properties. With the support of this NSF CAREER grant, we advanced the foundational understanding of processing-structure-property relationships of semiconductor nanostructures with controlled connections in multiple dimensions. Below, we summarize key outcomes of the program.

The underlying vision driving the research was based on a conceptual framework of analogies between atomic crystals and nanocrystal assemblies as designer solids. We integrated concurrent advances in the synthetic control over energy levels of the designer atom (nanocrystal), the quantum coupling across the designer bond (molecular linker) and the symmetry of the designer crystal (superlattice).

We published a comprehensive review of the rapid evolution of designer solids from early theoretical concepts to recent discoveries reporting the controlled fabrication of metamaterials with programmable electronic structures and their commercial application, particularly in next-generation of energy technologies. This review was published in:  Hanrath, T. Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films, 'Colloidal nanocrystal quantum dot assemblies as artificial solids' 2012, 30, 030802. This article was featured on the cover (see Figure 1) and was among the 20 most downloaded papers in JVSTA.

 

We disseminated new insights into the fundamental processing-structure-property relationships of these designer crystals in eleven peer reviewed papers and over twenty presentations at national conferences and university seminars. Collectively, these results allowed us to (1) map the electronic phase diagram of confined-but-connected semiconductor nanostructures with precise experimental control over the disorder and coupling of the system; (2) apply the understanding of correlated properties in the creation of artificial solids with electronic and optical properties by design, and (3) transform the fundamental understanding into a technological reality by developing and testing prototype photovoltaic and light-emitting test structures.

 

To demonstrate how new fundamental understanding of structure-property relationships can be translated to the fabrication of novel optoelectronic materials and devices, we prepared ‘micro-rainbow’ films in which the emission wavelength of the nanocrystal film can be tailored with micrometer precision. This approach may open doors to next general high-resolution display technologies. In a paper that was featured on the cover of the journal Nano Letters (see figure 2) we demonstrated, for the first time, how laser stripe annealing of CdSe nanocrystal thin films can yield structures with precisely programmed variations in quantum dot size.

 

Training and professional development of young researchers with interdisciplinary expertise in the analysis and fabrication of this exciting new class of materials is another key outcome of this program. This grant provided support for two graduate students  to be trained in high-resolution synchrotron-based X-ray structure characterization and the controlled formation of superlattices. Notably, the students developed processing conditions to form superlattices with grain sizes of upwards of 50µm; his protocol has now been adopted by other researchers at Cornell and elsewhere to train students and researchers in the formation of high-fidelity nanoparticle superlattices. One student Kaifu Bian, PhD is currently a postdoctoral researcher at Sandia National Laboratory; the other student Ben Treml, PhD is currently a NRC Postdoctoral Fellow at Air Force Research Laboratory.

Education and outreach were closely fully integrated with the research activities of this CAREER program.  The educational objectives were designed to: (1) integrate results from the research frontier and education of students ranging from high school to graduate school, and (2) capture the students enthusiasm and engagement in impending energy issues, encouraging their future contributions as the next generation of scientist and engineers. We worked with a class of elementary school students on a module termed ‘Why matter matters?’ and prepared lectures illustrating the analogies between playing with LEGOs and assembling colloidal quantum dot building blocks into desired structures. We have continued our engagement of high-school students and teachers at schools primarily serving underrepresented minorities in Harlem and Brooklyn, New York. During the past year we have worked with a class of 9th graders on interactive educational modules describing fundamental of light-matter interactions. (see Figure 3).  We modernized the chemical engineering senior design curriculum to include a ‘product design’ component (see Figure 4). At the graduate level, we organized an annual workshop on research ethics to educate graduate students about the proper conduct of research, ranging from the writing of and review of manuscripts to day-to-day activities in the lab.
